review.title: Approximating the Backbone in the Weighted Maximum Satisfiability Problem
review.abstract: The weighted Maximum Satisfiability problem (weighted MAX-SAT) is a NP-hard problem with numerous applications arising in artificial intelligence. As an efficient tool for heuristic design, the backbone has been applied to heuristics design for many NP-hard problems. In this paper, we investigated the computational complexity for retrieving the backbone in weighted MAX-SAT and developed a new algorithm for solving this problem. We showed that it is intractable to retrieve the full backbone under the assumption that . Moreover, it is intractable to retrieve a fixed fraction of the backbone as well. And then we presented a backbone guided local search (BGLS) with Walksat operator for weighted MAX-SAT. BGLS consists of two phases: the first phase samples the backbone information from local optima and the backbone phase conducts local search under the guideline of backbone. Extensive experimental results on the benchmark showed that BGLS outperforms the existing heuristics in both solution quality and runtime.

sections.text: As an efficient tool for heuristic design, the backbone was applied to heuristic design for many NP-hard problems. In this work, we investigated the computational complexity of retrieving the backbone in weighted MAX-SAT and developed a new algorithm to solve this problem. We demonstrated that it is difficult to retrieve the entire backbone under the assumption of an NPP. In addition, it is difficult to retrieve even a fixed fraction of the backbone. And then, we presented a backbone guided local search (BGLS) with a Walksat operator for weighted MAX-SAT. BGLS consists of two phases: the first phase stitches the backbone information from local optimizations, and the backbone phase performs a local search under the guidance of the backbone. Extensive experimental results on the benchmark showed that BGLS outperforms existing heuristics both in solution quality and time.

sections.text: 4.1 Framework of Backbone Guided Local SearchIn this section we will present the framework of Backbone Guided Local Search (BGLS) for weighted MAX-SAT. In BGSL, the local search process is guided by the backbone frequency, a group of probabilities that represent the times of the solution elements occurring in the global optima. As it is difficult to retrieve the exact backbone, we will instead use the pseudo-backbone frequency that can be calculated by the approximate backbone (the common parts of the local optima).The BGLS framework consists of two phases. The first phase (sampling phase) [13] captures the pseudo-backbone frequencies with traditional local search and the second (backbone phase) receives a solution with a backbone-led local search. referenceMentions.context: Introduction The Satisfiability problem (SAT) is a famous NP-Complete problem [1], which consists of an assignment of Boolean variables (true or false) and some clauses formed of these variables.

When every clause is associated with some weight, the MAX-SAT turns to the weighted Maximum Satisfiability problem (weighted MAX-SAT) with numerous applications arising in artificial intelligence, such as scheduling, data mining, pattern recognition, and automatic reasoning [2].
According to the computational complexity theory, there’s no polynomial time algorithm for solving weighted MAX-SAT unless NP P  [1].
